name: Blackhaw Viburnum
climate: Blackhaw Viburnum thrives well in a temperate climate zone.
It can tolerate cold winters, which makes it suitable for USDA zones 3-9.
This plant performs well in areas with moderate humidity levels.
It adapts well to different climatic conditions, from arid to moist.
sunlight: Blackhaw Viburnum prefers full sun for optimal growth and blooming.
It can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates.
Planting in an area with morning sun and afternoon shade is beneficial.
While it tolerates shade, more sunlight encourages better fruit production.
watering: Regular watering is essential, especially during the first growing season.
After establishment, it is relatively drought-tolerant and needs less water.
It appreciates consistent moisture but avoid overwatering to prevent root rot.
During extreme drought conditions, additional watering may be necessary.
soil: Prefers well-drained soil with rich organic matter for best growth.
Can tolerate a range of soil types, including clay and sandy soils.
Neutral to slightly acidic soil pH is ideal for optimal nutrient uptake.
Good drainage is crucial to prevent waterlogging and root health issues.
